questions.question: Question 1: Which of the following is the most common cause of sinusitis?
questions.explanation:
Nasal infections are the most common cause of sinusitis since sinus mucosa is a continuation of 
nasal mucosa and infections from the nose can travel directly by continuity or by way of 
submucosal lymphatics. The most common cause of acute sinusitis is viral rhinitis followed by bacterial invasion. Other causes: • Dental infections cause maxillary sinus infections. • Trauma • Swimming and diving.

questions.question: Question 2: Identify the most common sinus involved in sinusitis in adults.
questions.explanation:
The structure marked 4 is the maxillary sinus and is the most common sinus involved in acute 
sinusitis in adults. Order of frequency of sinuses involved in acute sinusitis in adults is maxillary > ethmoid > 
frontal > sphenoid. 427 
Sold by @itachibot

questions.question:
Question 3: A patient with sinusitis is least likely to present with which of the following symptoms? 417 
Sold by @itachibot
questions.explanation:
Diplopia is least likely to be seen in sinusitis. Patients with sinusitis typically present with a dull throbbing headache which worsens on moving 
the head or bending forward, nasal discharge and blockage, & constitutional symptoms like 
fever, general malaise and bodyache. Option A: Occipital headache can be seen in sphenoid sinusitis. Option B: Eyelid edema can be seen in frontal and ethmoidal sinusitis. Option D: Post-nasal drip and nasal discharge is a common finding in sinusitis.

questions.question:
Question 4: A 28-year-old IT professional with a recent history of upper respiratory tract infection has a 
headache that worsens during office hours. The headache comes upon waking, tends to be at 
its worst by about midday and improves as the day progresses. This characteristic periodicity 
is seen in?
questions.explanation:
Headache in frontal sinusitis shows characteristic periodicity, i.e. comes upon waking, gradually 
increases, reaches its peak by about midday, and then starts subsiding. It is also called office 
headache because of its presence only during office hours.

questions.question: Question 5: Which of the following is the most common sinusitis in children?
questions.explanation: The ethmoid sinus is the most common sinus involved in pediatric sinusitis. It usually occurs when the infection spreads through the lamina papyracea.

questions.question:
Question 6: A 12-year-old child diagnosed with sphenoid sinusitis was brought to the hospital with 
complaints of a fever and headache. The headache would most likely be localised to?
questions.explanation:
Headache in sphenoid sinusitis is localized to occiput or vertex. Frontal headache is seen in maxillary and frontal sinusitis. Headache in frontal sinusitis has 
characteristic periodicity.

questions.question:
Question 7: 418 
Sold by @itachibot A middle-aged man with a history of recurrent episodes of sinusitis for two years presented 
with complaints of a dull aching pain over his cheek, persistent nasal obstruction which 
worsens at night and an urge to constantly clear his throat. Which of the following anterior 
rhinoscopy findings is pathognomonic of the condition?
questions.explanation:
The given clinical history is suggestive of chronic maxillary sinusitis. Mucoid or mucopurulent 
discharge in the middle meatus seen on anterior rhinoscopy is a pathognomonic finding in 
chronic maxillary sinusitis. Other signs include mucosal edema primarily in the middle meatus as well as polyps. Clinically, 
patients present with nasal blockage, congestion, postnasal drip, reduced olfaction, and facial pain 
or pressure. On CT, mucosal changes within the osteomeatal complex and sinuses may be seen. 428 
Sold by @itachibot

questions.question:
Question 8: A 21-year-old female patient presented with fever, headache and, hawking sensation. 
Suspecting severe sinusitis, you order an X-ray of the PNS. Which view would be best in 
capturing all the paranasal sinuses in a single film?
questions.explanation:
The lateral view shows all the paranasal sinuses in a single film. The lateral side of the skull lies against the film, and an X-ray beam is projected perpendicular to 
the other side. Structures seen are: • Anterior and posterior extent of the sphenoid, frontal sinus • Maxillary sinuses • Ethmoid sinuses • Sella turcica • Alveolar process • Condyle and neck of the mandible. Note: Though all the abnormalities and diagnoses of Paranasal sinuses cannot be concluded 
through the lateral view alone, the lateral view radiographically covers all the sinuses in the same 
view.

questions.question:
Question 9: A patient with deviated nasal septum presents with a headache that starts upon waking and 
reaches its peak by about midday. On examination, she has upper eyelid oedema and 
tenderness on pressing just above the medial canthus. Which of the following X-ray views is 
preferred to best evaluate the sinus involved?
questions.explanation:
The given clinical scenario points to a diagnosis of frontal sinusitis. The best view for evaluating 
the frontal sinus is Caldwell's view. It is also known as occipitofrontal view or nose-forehead position. Structures seen are: • Frontal sinuses • Ethmoid sinuses 429 
Sold by @itachibot • Maxillary sinuses • Frontal process of the zygoma and the zygomatic process of the frontal bone • Superior margin of orbit and lamina papyracea • Superior orbital fissure • Foramen rotundum (inferolateral to superior orbital fissure)

questions.question: Question 10: Which of the following is used to make a definitive diagnosis of sinusitis?
questions.explanation: Diagnostic nasal endoscopy findings are used to confirm the diagnosis of sinusitis. Indications of diagnostic nasal endoscopy: • To diagnose any disease of the nose and PNS • To find the source of bleeding in epistaxis • To assess response to medical or surgical treatment of the nose and PNS disease • To take a precise biopsy from the nose and nasopharynx

questions.question:
Question 11: Which of the following complications would you not expect to see in a patient diagnosed with 
sinusitis?
questions.explanation:
Soft palate paralysis is not a known complication of sinusitis. Complications of paranasal sinus infection: • Local • Mucocele/Mucopyocele • Mucous retention cyst 430 
Sold by @itachibot • Osteomyelitis - Frontal bone (more common), maxilla • Orbital • Preseptal inflammatory oedema of lids • Subperiosteal abscess • Orbital cellulitis • Orbital abscess • Superior orbital fissure syndrome • Orbital apex syndrome • Intracranial • Meningitis • Extradural abscess • Subdural abscess • Brain abscess • Cavernous sinus thrombosis • Descending infections • Focal infections

questions.question: Question 12: Which of the following is the most common complication following acute rhinosinusitis?
questions.explanation:
Orbital cellulitis is the most common complication following acute rhinosinusitis. Complications of acute rhinosinusitis are typically classified as orbital (60–75 per cent), 
intracranial (15–20 per cent) and osseous (5–10 per cent), and local and descending infections.

questions.question:
Question 13: A 60-year-old lady presents with pain and swelling around the left upper eyelid region, 
diplopia and a headache. She gives a history of recurrent episodes of rhinosinusitis in the 
past. On examination, there is a downward, and outward deviation of the eyeball & the 
most prominent part of the swelling has a punctum with a mucopurulent discharge, just 
above the upper eyelid. Which of the following sinuses is most commonly involved in this 
complication?
questions.explanation:
The given clinical history and findings are suggestive of a mucocele secondary to frontal sinusitis. 
The frontal sinus is most commonly involved in mucocele formation. The sinuses commonly affected by mucocele in the order of frequency are the 
frontal>ethmoidal>maxillary>sphenoid The image given below shows a coronal MRI demonstrating a frontal mucocele and an orbital 
cystic mass. 431 
Sold by @itachibot

questions.question:
Question 14: 420 
Sold by @itachibot Which of the following statements is false about mucoceles?

options.a: Frontal sinus is most commonly involved
options.b: Presents as a cystic swelling in the superomedial quadrant
options.c: Eyeball is pushed downwards, forwards and medially

questions.explanation:
Eyeballs are pushed downwards, forwards and laterally. Option A: Frontal sinus is most commonly involved in mucocele. Option B: It presents as a cystic swelling in the superomedial quadrant of orbit. Option D: Treatment is frontoethmoidectomy with free drainage of the frontal sinus into the 
middle meatus.

questions.question:
Question 15: A young man was referred to the maxillofacial surgeon with complaints of pain and 
tenderness over the left cheek, inability to move the left eye, and numbness over the left 
forehead. He gave a history of chronic sinusitis for two years. Superior orbital fissure 
syndrome was suspected. Which of the following nerves is least likely to be involved in this 
condition?
questions.explanation:
The maxillary division of trigeminal nerve does not pass through the superior orbital fissure and 
thus, is the least likely nerve to be involved in this condition. Superior orbital fissure syndrome is characterized by the compression of cranial nerves III, IV, 
VI, and ophthalmic division of V. The superior orbital fissure lies between the greater and lesser 
wings of the sphenoid. The structures passing through include cranial nerves III, IV, VI, the 
ophthalmic branch of V, and the superior ophthalmic vein. 432 
Sold by @itachibot Orbital apex syndrome is superior orbital fissure syndrome with additional involvement of optic 
nerve and maxillary division of trigeminal nerve.

questions.question: Question 16: Which of the following statements is not true?

options.a: Osteomyelitis of maxilla is more common in children
options.b: Osteomyelitis of frontal bone is more common in adults
options.c: Ethmoidal sinusitis spreads through lamina papyracea
options.d: Pott’s puffy tumor is related to osteomyelitis of maxilla

questions.explanation:
Pott's puffy tumor refers to osteomyelitis of the frontal bone with the development of a 
subperiosteal abscess manifesting as a puffy swelling on the forehead or scalp. It usually occurs as 
a complication of frontal sinusitis. Option A: Osteomyelitis of the maxilla is more often seen in infants and children than adults 
because of the presence of spongy bone in the anterior wall of the maxilla. Option B: Osteomyelitis of frontal bone is more often seen in adults as frontal sinus is not 
developed in infants and children. Option C: Ethmoidal sinusitis spreads through lamina papyracea

questions.question:
Question 17: A middle-aged patient with a history of recurrent upper respiratory tract infections presents 
with diplopia and protrusion of the left eyeball. Inflammation of which of the following 
paranasal sinuses would most likely lead to this complication?
questions.explanation:
The given clinical vignette is suggestive of orbital complications secondary to sinusitis. The orbit 
and its contents are closely related to the ethmoid, frontal, and maxillary sinuses, but most of the 
complications, however, follow infection of ethmoids as they are separated from the orbit only by 
a thin lamina of bone called lamina papyracea.

questions.question:
Question 18: A procedure that involves puncturing and irrigating the sinus is planned for a patient with a 
history of chronic sinusitis. For which of the following paranasal sinuses is this procedure 
performed?
questions.explanation:
Proof puncture or antral lavage involves puncturing the medial wall of maxillary sinus in the 
region of inferior meatus to allow for irrigation and drainage of the sinus. 433 
Sold by @itachibot It is called proof puncture, as the presence of an infection can be proven during the procedure.

questions.question: Question 19: In which of the following conditions is antral lavage not indicated?
questions.explanation:
In acute maxillary sinusitis, antral lavage is actually contraindicated for the risk of osteomyelitis. Antral lavage is usually done therapeutically to remove pus and diagnostically for confirmation of 
chronic maxillary sinusitis. It can also be done to collect the specimen of the antral contents for 
culture and sensitivity, or cytological examination to exclude early malignancy.

questions.question:
Question 20: While performing a therapeutic antral lavage of the maxillary sinus, the patient developed a 
fatal complication. He stopped breathing, the colour of his face became ashen grey, and the 
pupils became dilated. Attempts to resuscitate the patient were futile, and he was declared 
dead after 20 minutes. Which of the following could be the most likely cause?
questions.explanation:
Air embolism is a rare but fatal complication that can occur during antral lavage through the veins 
that are damaged during the puncture. This complication can be prevented by avoiding the insufflation of air into the antrum after 
lavage.

questions.question:
Question 21: Which of the following sinuses is accessed via the Caldwell-Luc approach? 422 
Sold by @itachibot
questions.explanation:
Caldwell–Luc operation is a surgery where the maxillary antrum is opened through canine fossa 
by sublabial approach and pathology inside the antrum dealt with. 434 
Sold by @itachibot

questions.question:
Question 22: Which of the following structures is pierced while creating a nasoantral window in Caldwell 
Luc operation?
questions.explanation: Nasoantral window of <1.5cm in diameter is created through the inferior meatus.

questions.question: Question 23: Which of the following is the most common complication of Caldwell Luc operation?
questions.explanation:
The most common complication of Caldwell Luc operation is infraorbital nerve injury. Paraesthesia due to damage of the infraorbital nerve may be temporary or permanent and is 
reported in 21% of cases. 435 
Sold by @itachibot

questions.question: Question 24: What does FESS stand for?
questions.explanation:
FESS stands for Functional Endoscopic Sinus Surgery. FESS is a minimally invasive procedure that uses nasal endoscopes to enlarge the nasal drainage 
pathways of the paranasal sinuses to improve sinus ventilation and allow access to topical 
medications.

questions.question:
Question 25: Which of the following conditions is not an indication for functional endoscopic sinus 
surgery? 423 
Sold by @itachibot
questions.explanation: Cavernous sinus thrombosis is not an indication for functional endoscopic sinus surgery(FESS). Indications of FESS: • Chronic bacterial sinusitis unresponsive to adequate medical treatment • Recurrent acute bacterial sinusitis • Fungal sinusitis with fungal ball • Nasal polyps • Mucocele • Control of epistaxis • Removal of foreign body from the nose or sinus • Barotrauma sinusitis (pain in the face during descent in aircraft or descent whilst scuba diving)

questions.question: Question 26: Which of the following conditions is a contraindication for endoscopic sinus surgery?
questions.explanation:
436 
Sold by @itachibot Acute rhinosinusitis with epidural abscess is a contraindication for functional endoscopic sinus 
surgery. The endoscopic approach is contraindicated in the presence of an intracranial complication of 
acute infection such as: • Meningitis • Subperiosteal abscess • Epidural abscess • Cavernous sinus thrombosis • Any visual loss Note: Endoscopic sinus surgery is indicated in chronic bacterial rhinosinusitis, allergic fungal 
sinusitis with mycetoma and repair of cerebrospinal fluid leak.

questions.question:
Question 27: Which of the following structures cannot be accessed by performing an endoscopic nasal 
surgery?
questions.explanation:
Cerebellum cannot be accessed by performing endoscopic nasal surgery. Apart from the nose and paranasal sinuses, endoscopic surgery can be used to access the orbit, 
optic nerve, lacrimal sac, and pituitary gland. Indications of advanced nasal endoscopic techniques: • Removal of benign tumors, e.g. inverted papillomas or angiofibromas • Orbital abscess or cellulitis management. • Dacryocystorhinostomy • Repair of CSF leak • Pituitary surgery • Optic nerve decompression • Orbital decompression for Graves’ disease • Control of posterior epistaxis (endoscopic clipping of sphenopalatine artery) • Choanal atresia

questions.question:
Question 28: A 45-year-old-man with a history of chronic sinusitis unresponsive to medications is planned 
for functional endoscopic sinus surgery. Which of the following is the first step in the 
procedure?
questions.explanation:
Uncinectomy where uncinate process is incised with sickle knife and removed with Blakesley 
forceps is the first definitive surgical step in FESS. 437 
Sold by @itachibot

questions.question:
Question 29: 424 
Sold by @itachibot You are a third-year ENT resident performing a functional endoscopic sinus surgery on a 
patient diagnosed with chronic maxillary sinusitis. During the procedure, the lateral wall of 
the infundibulum is punctured adjacent to the maxillary sinus ostium. Why is this step done?
questions.explanation:
Infundibulotomy, also known as uncinectomy, is the first surgical step in FESS and it is done to 
approach the middle meatus.

questions.question: Question 30: Water’s view is used to best visualize which of the following sinuses?
questions.explanation:
Water’s view is used to best visualize the maxillary sinus. Frontal and ethmoidal sinuses can also 
be visualized. Sphenoid sinus can be seen in Water's view with open mouth. It is also known as the occipitomental view. The X-ray beam is angled at 37°-45° to the 
orbitomeatal line. The recommended imaging views for different sinuses are as follows: • Ethmoidal sinus: Rheese's view • Frontal sinus: Caldwell's view • Sphenoid sinus: Hirtz view 438 
Sold by @itachibot

questions.question:
Question 31: The radiograph shown below is done for better assessment of the frontal sinus. What is the 
common name of this view?
questions.explanation:
The frontal sinus is best seen in Caldwell's view (occipitofrontal view or nose-forehead position). The structures seen in Caldwell's view include: • Frontal sinuses (seen best) • Ethmoid sinuses • Maxillary sinuses • Frontal process of the zygoma and the zygomatic process of the frontal bone • Superior margin of the orbit and lamina papyracea • Superior orbital fissure 439 
Sold by @itachibot • Foramen rotundum (inferolateral to superior orbital fissure) The nose and forehead are touching the X-ray film and the X-ray beam is projected 15 degrees 
caudally in Caldwell's view. Other options: Option A: Water's view (occipitomental view or nose-chin position) is a radiographic view where 
an X-ray beam is angled at 45 degrees to the orbitomeatal line. Structures seen are the maxillary 
sinus (best seen), sphenoid sinus (if the film is taken with an open mouth), frontal sinus, zygoma, 
zygomatic arch, nasal bone, and infratemporal fossa. Option C: Pierre's view is the occipitomental with an open mouth. It helps in visualizing the 
sphenoid sinus as well, in addition to the sinuses that can be seen in water's view. Option D: Towne's view is an angled anteroposterior radiograph of the skull. Structures seen are 
the petrous part of the pyramids, arcuate eminence, superior semicircular canal, mastoid antrum, 
internal auditory canal, tympanic cavity, cochlea, and external auditory canal. This view is taken 
for acoustic neuroma and apical petrositis. 440 
Sold by @itachibot Anatomy and Physiology of Pharynx
